message: They just had a massive spree on a number of gaming services, including taking down the EVE and League of Legends login servers.

So, for those that don't know, a lot of the recent hack attacks on major (particularly gaming, it seems) websites are from one "group" called LulzSec, who do it with the aim of pointing out bad security but mostly "for the lulz".
I'd totally cheer for them if they ever take down NeoGAF.
The very dregs of society, or a valuable free lesson in network security? DISCUSS.

It's getting a bit ridiculous. I haven't been following the whole development too closely, so I know if they've released some of the info they've took during these attacks. It's fine if you're trying to show these companies that their network security's not up to scratch, but actually releasing the info goes a bit too far I feel.

I just read a few articles on them, and I'm interested in _what the point_ of their attacks are. Surely it cannot just be 'for the lulz'?

And its quite dick of them to knock out LoL, given the EU server is already as fragile as it is without a DDoS attack.

LulzSec seems that Tuesday's rampage wasn't lulzy enough, and have took out the CIA's website _and_ switchboard. http://arstechnica.com/security/news/2011/06/lulzsec-rampage-continues-62k-e-mails-and-passwords-cia-under-attack.ars
And now reports are coming in regarding Sega, Xbox Live, Facebook, Paypal... And I can't log into Paypal at the moment to change once again my password.
This last batch of attacks were all linked to a single site where users used the same login info for the other services. I forget the specifics, but it was some sort of artist portfolio website?
This firmly hits the point where I see LulzSec as a force for evil. You're not proving anything by making someone's Paypal information publically available, you're ruining lives.
